subject: Art & Design
title: Monospaced Fonts: Every Letter Gets Equal Width
description: A micro-lesson that makes Monospaced Fonts: Every Letter Gets Equal Width usable.

hook.text: In a monospaced font, the letter 'i' takes the same width as 'm.' It looks odd ‚Äî and that's the point.

buildup.text: Typewriters needed fixed-width letters because the carriage moved one step per keystroke.

discovery.text: Programmers use monospaced fonts because code alignment depends on consistent character widths.

twist.text: Courier New was designed for IBM typewriters in 1955. It's still the default monospace in many systems.

climax.text: Modern monospace fonts like JetBrains Mono and Fira Code add ligatures for coding symbols.

punchline.text: Equal width per letter. Unequal beauty. Maximum function.

quiz.question: Why do programmers prefer monospaced fonts?
options: Consistent character width keeps code aligned
Color coding only works with monospace
